name: 2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid
Reason: 2-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzoic acid has a melting point of -120.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a hydroxyl group and a methoxy group. The hydroxyl group can increase the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding, which can rigidify the structure and enhance intermolecular interactions. The methoxy group can also contribute to the melting point due to its ability to increase the molecular weight and rigidity. The exact contribution for each group is difficult to estimate, but we can consider a rough estimate of +20 to +30°C for the hydroxyl group and +10 to +20°C for the methoxy group.
